text: Remember: emotions linger.
author: You.

text: Storing-up is not higher-order thinking.
author: You.

text: Look in the mirror until you don't see yourself.
author: You.

text: What perspective have you dismissed?
author: You.

text: Let the prefrontal cortex fill in the blank.
author: You.

text: What does pain, and pleasure, and numbness feel like?
author: You.

text: Easiest way to learn: fail.
author: You.

text: Remember: you don't have the full story.
author: You.

text: Look at it from the view of the minority.
author: You.

text: It's not 'just as simple' as honest, hard work.
author: You.

text: What things other than reasoning, memory, and comprehension make up intelligence?
author: You.

text: Let it stay uncategorized.
author: You.

text: Why does misery love company?
author: You.

text: It will be harder tomorrow.
author: You.

text: You have permission to move on.
author: You.

text: What keeps showing up on your brain radar?
author: You.

text: Remember something. How did you remember it?
author: You.

text: Magic is found in not understanding.
author: You.

text: Is this something that matters? Is this something you actually to control?
author: You.

text: Does it call for a scientist or a philosopher?
author: You.

text: How does it *not* fit into a nice, little heuristic?
author: You.

text: Is the nuance gratuitous?
author: You.

text: Make a compromise.
author: You.

text: Avoid superheroism.
author: You.

text: Where does the present moment fit in geologic time?
author: You.

text: Take the negative connotation out of 'overgrown'.
author: You.

text: 95 percent of the work consists of completing mundane tasks.
author: You.

text: Are you going to mourn, or cherish, what you lost?
author: You.

text: Accept that you can't do it perfectly. Then do it perfectly sufficiently.
author: You.

text: Be an adult community college student.
author: You.

text: Function like it's the post-apocalypse and you're Tom Hanks.
author: You.

text: Don't let productivity get in the way of getting things done.
author: You.

text: Stop thinking about it.
author: You.

text: Deprioritize completion.
author: You.

text: Now move up one level of abstraction/perspective.
author: You.

text: Yes, it's an old idea. Make it new.
author: You.

text: More likely than not, they just haven't thought about it like you have.
author: You.

text: Assume this is the best the circumstances will get. Proceed from there.
author: You.

text: Stop. Do the one, most important thing now.
author: You.

text: Assume the same basic hardware.
author: You.

text: Low-hanging fruit is, more often than not, rotten.
author: You.

text: Something backfired. That's interesting!
author: You.

text: It's like a rude person praising someone for being humble.
author: You.

text: There's a hole in the bucket list.
author: You.

text: Separate your thoughts from your self.
author: You.

text: Stop trying to get to the end.
author: You.

text: This could be the last time you will ever do it.
author: You.

text: Be aware that you are watching it.
author: You.

text: Listen completely.
author: You.

text: Are you really focusing or just telling yourself to focus?
author: You.

text: It'll be over in ten seconds.
author: You.

text: Remember: you always start from a place of assuming you understand.
author: You.

text: There is a time to be mindful and a time to be in it.
author: You.

text: Ten minutes before it be far from it.
author: You.

text: With respect, Marie Kondo, it's always going to be messy.
author: You.

text: Right now is an opportunity to think about it differently.
author: You.

text: Spend one minute placing it in your mental filing cabinet.
author: You.

text: Good work is not painless.
author: You.

text: You can't be more creative than what you can think of.
author: You.

text: Distinguish good omission from bad omission.
author: You.

text: You don't have it, but you don't own it, so stop feeling bad it was taken.
author: You.

text: How much would it matter if you put in ten percent less, or ten percent more, effort?
author: You.

text: Visualize your todo list as a sideways Tetris game.
author: You.

text: You must lose it in order to remember it (find, then lose, then find).
author: You.

text: What will your future self say about your resistance to change? (Ex: what will future generations say about our reluctance to use nuclear power and lab-grown meat?)
author: You.

text: Now focus on your tailwinds.
author: You.
context: From https://hiddenbrain.org/podcast/the-enemies-of-gratitude/ , this is about how we tend to focus on what's going against us rather than with us, and we focus on our challenges and assume that other people aren't having similar challenges.
